content.value_statement: Build reusable slash commands for Claude Code. Learn command structure, YAML frontmatter options, dynamic arguments, file references, and bash execution to automate common workflows.
actual_capabilities: Create slash commands with YAML frontmatter configuration
Organize commands with namespacing and subdirectories
Integrate commands with plugin agents and skills
limitations: Commands are text prompts, not executable scripts
Commands run within Claude Code tool permissions
File references are read-only, not write operations

best_practices: Use allowed-tools to restrict command permissions to minimum required
Add argument-hint to document expected arguments for user autocomplete
Test commands with different argument combinations before deployment
anti_patterns: Using Bash(*) instead of specific tool restrictions like Bash(git:*)
Writing commands as messages to users instead of instructions to Claude
Skipping error handling for missing arguments or file references

faq.question: Where do I store slash commands?
faq.answer: Project commands go in .claude/commands/, personal commands in ~/.claude/commands/, and plugin commands in plugin-name/commands/.

faq.question: How do I restrict what tools a command can use?
faq.answer: Use the allowed-tools field in frontmatter. For example: allowed-tools: Read, Bash(git:*).

faq.question: Can I pass arguments to slash commands?
faq.answer: Yes. Use $1, $2 for positional arguments or $ARGUMENTS for all arguments as a single string.

faq.question: How do I include file contents in a command?
faq.answer: Use @file-path syntax. For example: Review @$1 to include the file specified as argument $1.

faq.question: What is the !`command` syntax for?
faq.answer: It executes bash commands and includes their output in the command context. Useful for git status, npm scripts, and more.

faq.question: How do I organize many commands?
faq.answer: Use subdirectories for namespacing. For example: .claude/commands/git/commit.md becomes /commit (project:git).
